content: round of thumb knit 8 stitches in pattern ending with a purl stitch bind off 21 stitches in pattern by knitting and passing the stitch over the next all stitches will be knit except for the very last stitch will be purled and a knit stitch passes over it 17 21 stitches bound off between purl columns you want your bind off to be firm so the thumb doesn t sag but make sure it s not so tight it s uncomfortable there are 33 41 stitches per mitt on the needles after this round continue in pattern next round knit in pattern up to the gap left by casting off the thumb stitches to bridge the gap cast on 3 stitches with backwards loop cast on continue knitting in pattern after this round you ll be back to 36 44 stitches remember to maintain the ribbing pattern palm all the hard work is over keep knitting in pattern till your mitt is the desired length you can add more stripes if you d like or just keep knitting till your fingers are sufficiently covered if you d like to try on your mitts i find it s easiest to try on mitt b right at the beginning of the round while mitt a is out of the way and on the needles just be careful not to loose any stitches off the needles or disrupt the magic loop once the palm is to your liking or you re running out of yarn… finish off with your favorite stretchy bind off i personally prefer the icelandic bind off as you bind off the first half of mitt a you ll be left with one stitch on the needles with mitt b blocking your access to finish casting off the rest of mitt a just grab that one leftover stitch from mitt a with a locking stitch marker or safety pin and slide it off the needles cast off mitt b in its entirety and as you come back around to the back half of mitt a put that one leftover stitch back on the needles and continue casting off weave in your ends and you re done black and gray gloves knit in shepherds wool storm and black purple gloves knit in cascade 220 superwash purple heather
